div.p:
LEt us call to our
Father in heaven
through our Lord
Jesus Christe,
that he wil vouch
safe to poure his
grace into us, that
we may to our no smal profit, dispatch
and expound the last part of the Arti
cles of Christian beliefe.

The ninth Article of faith is this,
The holie Catholique Churth, the
communion of saintes. After the con
fession of our beleif in the holy Trini
tie, and in the mysterie of the Sonne
of God our Lord Jesus Christ, and
lastly in the holie Ghost the sanctifier
and restorer of all: nowe in the fourth
part is reckoned up the fruite and po
wer, the effect and ende of faith, and
what doth come to, and is bestowed on
the faithfull. There commeth to them
communion of God and all saintes,
sanctification remission of sinnes, the
resurrection of the fleshe and life e
verlasting.break Of which I will speake
in order as they lye so far forth as the
bountifull Lord shall give me abilitie.
Nowe then here we have to rehearse
out of the eight Article this worde I
believe, we must(I meane) say, I be
lieve the holie Catholique Church.
Some unlearned there are which hold
opinion that in this point of our con
fession we should say, I believe in the
holy Church. The reason that leades
them so to thinke is this, because they
finde written in the Constantinopli
tane Creede, And in the holy Ghost the
Lorde that giveth life, who proceedeth
from the father & the sonne who toge
ther with the father & the son is to bee
worshipped and glorified, who spake
by the Prophetes in one Catholiqu,
and Apostolique Church. For these
wordes they doe so distinguishe that
as they doe repeate out of the premises
these wordes, I believe, and make
this the sense, I believe in the holie
Ghost the Lorde : even so here againe
they doe repeate these wordes, I be
lieve, making this to be the sense, I
believe in one Catholique and Apo
stolique Church. But this is more
than needeth, yea and against all god
linesse doe they wrest these wordes
of the Creede. For this, In one Ca
tholique and Apostolique Church, is
not referred to the Verbe, I believe,
but to the holy Ghost, because hee
spake by the Prophetes in one Ca
tholique and Apostolique Church,
For our meaning is, and we confesse
that one and the same spirite did all
thinges in both Testamentes, contra
rie to the opinion of them which ima
gined that there were two spirits con
trarie one to the other

Moreover, Saint Cyprian in his
exposition of the Apostles Creede,
sayth: He sayd not in the holy churth,
nor in the remission of sinnes, nor
in the resurrection of the bodie. For
if hee had added the preposition, In,
then had the force of those clauses
beene all one with the force of that
that went before, For in those wordes
wherein our beliefe touching the
Godhead is set downe we say, in God
the Father, In Jesus Christ his Son, and
in the holy ghost:but in the rest where
the speach is not of the Godhead, but
touching the creatures or mysteries,
the preposition In is not added, that
we may say in the holy Church, but
that the holy Church is to be beleeved
not as we beleve in God, but as a con
gregation gathered together to God,
and that the forgivenesse of sinnes is to
be beleeved, not that we ought to be
leeve in the forgivenesse of sinnes: and
that the resurreetion of the flesh is to
>be beleeved, not that we ought to be-
leeve in the resurreetion of the fleshe.
So then by this syllable, In, the Creator
is discerned from the Creatures, and
that that is Gods fro that that is mans,
This saith Cyprian.

S. Augustine in his booke De Fide
& Symbolo hath, I beleeve in the holie
Churche, not l beleeve in the holie
Church. There are alledged also his
wordes in his Epistle ad Neohhytos,
touching consecration Distinct. 4. cap.
1. We said not that ye had to beleeve
in the Church as in God, but under
stand how we said, y ye being conver
saunt in the holie Catholique Churth
should beleeve in God.

Much more evidently doth Pascha
sius in the first Chap. of his first booke
De Spiritu Sancto say, we beleeve the
Church as the mother of regenerati
on: we do not beleeve in the Church
as the authour of salvation. Hee that
beleeveth in the Churthe, beleeveth
in man. For man hath not his being
of the Church, but the Church be
ganne by man. Leave off therefore
this blasphemous perswasion to thinke
that thou hast to beleeve in anie
worldly Creature, since thou mayest
not beleeve neither in Angell nor Ar
changell. The unskilfulnesse of some
have drawne and taken the preposi
tion, In, from the sentence that goeth
next before. and put it to that that
followeth, adding thereto also too
too shamelesly somewhat more than
needed. This hath Paschasius in
that booke of his which saint Grego
rie the great Bishoppe of Bome liked
verie well of.

What say ye to that moreover that
Thomas of Aquine reasoning of faith,
in the seconde booke Part 2. Artie, o
dueest, 1, sayth: If we say, I beleeve in
the holie Churth, wee must under
stande that our faith is referred to
the holie Ghost which sanctifieth the
Churth: and so make the sense to be
thus: I beleeve in the holie spirite that
sanctifieth the Churth. But it is better
and according to the common use not
to adde at all the syllable, In, but sim
ply to say the holy Catholique churth
even as also Pope Leo sayeth. Thus
hath Thomas,
So nowe ye have hearde the opi
nions of the auncient Doctours of
the Churche, Cyprian, Augustine,
Gregorie, Paschasius, Pope Leo, and
also of Thomas of Aquine which
taught now in the latter times. And
(dearely beloved) ye doe understand
by proofes taken out of the Canoni
call Scripture, that we must acknow
ledge and confesse the holy Catholique
Church, but not beleeve in the holie
Catholique Church.
And nowe wee have to see what
that is that is called the Church, and
what is called the Catholique church.
Ecclesia, which worde wee use for
the Church is properly an assembly,
it is I say where the people are called
out or gathered together to heare
somewhat touching the affaires of the
common weale. In this present
treatise it is the companie, communi
on, congregation, multitude, or fel
lowship of all that professe the name
of Christ. Catholique is as muche
to say as, this fellowship is universal,
as that that is extended through all
places and ages. For the Church of
Christ is not restrained into any cor
ner among the Donatists in Aphricar
it stretcheth out it selfe through the
compasse of the worlde and unto all a
ges, and doth conteine all the faithfull
from the first Adam even unto the ve
rie last Saint that shall be remaining
before the end of the worlde.

This universall Church hath her
particular Churches, I meane the
Church of Adam & of the patriarches,
the Church of Moses and of the Pro
phetes before the birth of Christe, the
Christian Church which is so named
of Christe him selfe, and the Apostoli
call Church gathered together by the
Apostles doctrine in the name of
Christ. And finally it containeth these
particular Churches, as the Churche
of Jerusalem, of Antioch, of Aleran
dria, of Rome, of Asia, of Aphrica, of
Europe, of the Cast, of the West, ac
And yet all these Churches as it were
members of one bodie under the only
heade Christ (for Christ alone is the
head of his Church not onely trium
phant, but militant also) do make one
onelye Catholike Church: in which
there are not to be founde either here
sies or schismes : and for that cause is
it called the true Church, to wit, of the
right and true opinion, judgement,
faith and doctrine. For in the church
onelie is true faith, and without the
Church of God is neither anie trueth,
nor yet salvation,

So then in this article wee confesse
that all the faithful dispersed through
out the whole compasse of the earth,
and they also that at this time live in
heaven, as many I say as are alreadie
saved, or shal even until the verie end
of the world be borne to bee saved, are
one bodie, having gotten fellowship
and participation with God, & a mu
tuall communion among themselves.
And for because no man can be made
one with God, unlesse he also be holy &
pure, even as God is holy ad pure,
therefore we believe that the Church
is holy, that is, that it is sanctified by
God the Father in the bloude of the
Sonne, and the gift of the holy Ghoste,
We have hearde testimonies enough
in the former Sermons. Therefore
this one of Paule shall bee sufficient
which he writeth to the Ephesians,
Christe loved the Church and gave
him selfe for it, to sanetifye, and to
cleanse it in the fountaine of Water
through the worde, to make it unto
him selfe a glorious Church not ha
ving spot or wrinekle. & By which
words we understand that the church
is called undefiled & altogether clean,
not in respect of it selfe, but because of
Christ. For the Church of Christ is so
farre foorth holy as that yet everie day
it doth goe forwarde in profiting, and
is never perfect so long as it liveth on
the earth. And yet notwithstanding
the holinesse of it is moste absolutely
perfect in Christe. Whereunto verilie
belongeth that notalbe saying of the
Lord. He that is washed, hath no need
but to wash his feete onely, for hee is
wholy cleane. For the faithfull are
purely cleansed by Christe, who wa
sheth them with his bloud, but yet be
cause the fleshe doeth strive with the
spirite solong as life remaineth on the
earth, therefore the godly have neede
with faith and the holie ghost to wash
and wipe their feete, that is, the re
liques and spots wherewith they are
disteined by their daily conversation
in this worlde.

But nowe whereunto belongeth
this that is added: The Commumion
of saintes: These wordes are neither
read in Cyprian, nor Augustine, nor
yet by them expounded. Wherefore
it is likely that they were added for
the better understanding of that which
went before:for that it might appeare
that the catholique church is the fel
lowship or company of the faythtull,
he added The Communion of Saintes,
as if he should have said, which church
is a communion of Saintes. Paule
called them sainctes, which for their
faith are sanctified by the bloud and
spirit of God. Also this word Commu
nion is verie evident and comfortalbe.
For first the meaning thereof is that
betwirt god & us there is a communi
on, that is a felowship & participation,
and so consequently a parting betwirt
us and all good and heavenly things.
And then also we understand, that we
are fellowes and partakers with all ye
Saincts that are living either in hea
ven or on earth. For we are members
of the under one heade Christ. For the
Apostle John saith: That which wee
have seene and heard we declare unto
you, that yee also may have fellow ship
with us, and that your fellowship may
be with the father, and his sonne lesus
Christ. Hereunto appertayneth that
trimme similitude of the bodie & mem
bers under one heade, which ye Apostle
Paule handleth at large in deede: but
what is hee that can worthily enough
set foorth the great goodnesse of Gods
gift & benefit, in that we are made fel
low partners of God, with whom we
are most neerely conioined, and have a
part in al his good & heavenly thinges
what can be more delightfull to our
eares, than to heare that all the saints
as well in heaven as in earth, are our
brethren, and that we again are mem
bers, partners, and felowes with the
Blessed be God which hath so liberally
bestowed his blessing on us in Christ
his sonne. To this place belongeth the
discourse uppon the Sacramentes, of
which, and of the Church, I meane at
an other time more fully to intreate,
This for the present time is sufficient,
For this ye I have said doth abundatly
enough expresse & set out the fruite of
faith in the father, the sonne, & the holy
ghost, to wit, ye we have participation
with God, and al the saints, and that
in this fellowship we are sanctlfied from
al filth or uncleannesse, being cleansed,
and holie in Christ our Lorde,

Now followeth the tenth article of
our beleefe, which is: The forgivenesse
of sinnes. The second fruit or commo
ditie of our beleefe in God the father,
the son, and the holy ghost, is here set
foorth, that is, the remission of sinnes,
which, although it be cotained in sanc
tification spoken of in the last article,
is in this place notwithstanding more
lively expressed. Without the Church
as it were without the arke of Noe is
no salvatio: but in ye Church, I meane
in the felowship of Christ, & the saints
is ful forgivenesse of al offences. That
this may be the better understoode I
will divide it into some partes.

First of al it is needeful to acknow
ledge & confesse, that we are sinners, &
that by nature, and our owne proper
merits, we are the children of wrath &
damnation. For S. John doth not in
vaine nor without a cause call everie
one a liar that saith he hath no sin. And
God which knoweth the harts of men
hath commaunded us even till the last
gaspe to pray, saying: Forgive us our
debts. Moreover, in the Gospell wee
have two excellent examples of men o
penly confessing their sins to God, the
prodigall sonne, I say, and the Publi
can in S. Luke. Let us therfore thinke
that we are all sinners, as Paule also
taught: yea, as he hath evidently proo
ved in the first chap, to the Romanes, &
let us freely confesse to God our sinnes
with David in the 32. & 52. Psal, say
ing: My sinne have I made knowen to
thee, & mine iniquitie I have not hid.
I have saide: I will confesse mine un
righteousues against my selfe, & thou
hast forgiven the iniquitie of mine
offence, Have mercie on me O God,
accordingto thy great merey, Ze. The
Secondarily, let us believe that all
these sins of ours are pardoned & for
given of God, not for the acknowledg
ing and confessing of our sinnes, but
for the merit and bloud of the sonne of
God : not for our owne workes or me
rites, but for the truth and mercie or
grace of God. For we do plainely pro
sesse, saying: I believe the forgivenesse
of sins: We say not, I buy, or by gifts
doe get, or by workes obtaine the for
givenesse of sins, but I believe the for
givenesse of sinnes. And the worde re
mission or forgivenesse doth signifie a
free pardoning, by a metaphore taken
of creditors and debitors For the cre
ditor forgiveth the debitor, when hee
is not able to paye : therefore remissi
on is a forgiving according to the say
in of our saviour in the Gospell: A
certaine lender had two debitors: and
when they were not able to paie, he
forgave them both. Hereunto belong
eth that also in the Lords prayer: And
forgive us our debtes. For our debtes
are our sinnes, them doe we request to
be remitted, that is, to be forgiven us.
In this sense also, saith S. Paul: To
him that worketh is the reward recko
ned, not of grace, but of due debt: But
to him that worketh not, but belee
veth on him that justifieth the ungod
lie, his faith is counted for righteous
nesse: Even as David describeth the
blessednesse of that man unto whom
God imputeth righteousnesse without
workes, saying: Blessed are they whose
unrighteousnesse are forgiven, and
whose sinnes are covered. Blossed is
that man to whom the Lorde will not
impute sinne. Wherefore in respect of
us which have not wherewithall to
repaie, our sinnes are freely forgiven,
but in respect of Gods justice they are
forgiven for the merit and satistaction
Moreover, it is not the sinnes of a
few men, of one or two ages, or a fewe
and certaine number of sins are forgi
ven onely, but the sinnes of all men, of
all ages, the whole multitude of sins,
whatsoever is, and is called sin, whe
ther it be originall, or actuall, or any o
ther else, to be short all sinnes are for
given us. Which we do hereby learne,
because the onely sacrifice of Christ is
effectuall enough to wash away all the
offences of all sinners, which by faith
come to the mercie seat of Gods grace.
And yet by this we doe not teach men
to sinne, because the Lorde hath long
since made satisfaction for sinnes: but
if any man doe sinne, we teach him to
hope well, and not to despaire, but to
flee to the throne of Grace. For there
we say, that Christ sitting at the right
hande of the father, is the Lambe of
God that taketh away the fins of the
worlde. And in the Creede verily it is
expresly sayde: I believe the forgive
nesse of sinnes, and not of sinne. For
when we say of sinnes, we acknow
ledge that God forgiveth all finnes.
For to let passe the proofes hereof out
of the 3, & 5. of Paul to the Romanes,
those out of S. John the Apostle & Ev
nangelist shall be susficent, who in his
Epistle testifieth and sayth: The bloud
of Jesus Christ clenseth us from everie
sinne. Loe, he saith from everie sinne,
Hee, I say, that saith from everie one,
excepteth none, unlesse it be ye which ye
Lorde himelfe excepted, I meane the
sinne against the holy ghost, for which
the very same S. John forbiddeth us
to pray. Againe also he saith: If we ac
knowledge our sinnes, God is faithfull
and just, to forgive us our sinnes, and
to clense us fro all our unrighteousnes,
The Apostle thought it not enough to
say barely, To forgive us our sinnes,
but that he might declare the thing as
it is indeede so plainely, that it might
easily bee understoode, hee addeth more
over this saying: And to clense us from
al our unrighteousnesse. Loe, heere hee
saith againe from all unrighteousnes,
And for because some caviller might
peradveture, make this obiection and
say. This kinde of docrine maketh
men sluggish and slow to amendment.
For men under the pretence of Gods
grace will not cease to sinne : therfore
John in his 2. chap, auntwereth their
obiection and saith: Babes, these things
write I to you that yee sinne not: and
if anie man sinne, we have an advocate
with the father Jesus Christ the righ
teous. And he is the attonemet for our
sins: and not for our sins onely, but also
for the sinnes of al the worlde. Wher
fore it is assuredly true, that by the
death of Christ all sinnes are forgiven
them that believe.

Moreover, the Lord alone forgiveth
sins. For it is the glorie of God alone
to forgive sinnes, and of unrighteous,
to make men righteous. Therefore,
whereas men are said to forgive sins,
that is to be understood of their mini
sterie, and not of their power. The mi
nister pronounceth to the people, that
for Christ his sake their sinnes are for
given : and in so saying hee deceyueth
them not: For God in deede forgi
veth the sins of them that beleeve:ac
cording to that saying: whose sinnes
so we reade not that ye Apostles heard
yee forgive, they are forgiven them
And this is done so often as the worde
of the Gospel is preached, so that there
be no neede to faine that auricular con
fession and private absolution at the
priests hand is necessarie for the re
mission of sinnes. For as auricular
confession was not in use among the
Saints before the comming of Christ, So we reade not that & Apostles heard
private confession, or used private ab
solution in the Church of Christ. It
is enough for us to confesse our sinnes
to God, who because hee seeth our
heartes, ought therefore most rightly
to heare our confessiss. It is enough if
wee, as S. James teacheth us, do one
to another betwirt our selves confesso
our faultes and offences, and so after
pardon asked, returne into mutuall
favour againe. It is enough for us to
heare the Gospel, promising ye forgive
nesse of our sinnes through Christ, if
wee believe. Let us therefore believe
the forgivenesse of sinnes, and praye to
the Lord that he wil vouchsafe to give
and increase in us this same beleefe,
These things were of olde and in the
Primitive Church effectuall enough
to obtaine pardon and full remission of
sinnes: & as they were, so are they un
doubtedly at this day sufficient too,

Furthermore, the Lord doth so par
don our sinnes, not that they shoulde
not be any more in us, nor leave their
reliques behind them as a sting in our
flesh, but that they should not be im
puted to us to our damnation. Concu
piscence sticketh fast, and sheweth it
selfe in our flesh, striving still with the
good spirite of god, even in the holie
ones so long as life lasteth on this
earth. Here therefore wee have neede
of long waching and much fasting, to
draw from the flesh the nourishmet of
evil, & often praiers to call to God for
ayde, that wee bee not overcome of the
evill. And if any man shal hap to faile
for feeblenes, and be subdued of temp
tation, let him not yeeld himself by ly
ing still, to be caught in the divels net,
let him rise up agayne by repentance,
and runne to Christ, beleeving, that by
the death of Christ this fall of his shal
be forgiven him. And so often shall
he have recourse to him as hee shall be
vanquished by concupiscence and sin,
For to this ende shoote al the exhorta
tions of the Prophets & Apostles, cal
ling on still to returne to the Lord.
Finally, the Lorde doth so forgive
our sinnes, that hee will never once re
memder them againe. For so he fore
teld us by Jere. in his 31. cha. He ther
fore doth not punish us. For hee hath
not onely forgiven the fault, but also
the punishment due for the sin. Nowe
then, whereas the Lord sometime doth
whip us with his scourges, and whip
peth us for our sinnes indeede : as the
holie Scripture doth plainly declare,
hee doth it not to the intent, that with
our affliction wee shoulde make satis
faction for the sinnes wee have com
mitted: For then should the death of
Christ be of none effect: but the Lord
with whipping doeth chastise us, & by
whipping us doth let us understand,
that hee liketh not of the sinnes which
wee have committed, and hee doth free
ly forgive: By whipping us also he
maketh us exaples to other: least they
sinne too, and cutteth from us all occa
sion of sinning, and by the Crosse doeth
keepe our patience in ure. This thus
farre, touching the forgivenes of sins,
Of which I have said somewhat in
my sermon of faith that justifieth: and
elsewhere.

The eleventh Article is this, The
resurrection of the fleshe. These two
Articles, this and the twelfth shutte
up as briefly as may bee, the most ex
cellent fruit of faith, and summe of al
perfection, they wrap up I say, the end
of faith, in confessing life everlasting, &
the ful & perfect salvation of the whole
man. For ye whole ma shalbe saved, as
well in soule as bodie. For as man by
sinne did perish both in body and soule,
so ought he to be restored againe both
bodily and ghostly : and as hee ought
so was hee by Christ restored againe
The soule of man verily is a spirite
and dieth not at all:the body is earthly
and therefore dieth and rotteth. For
which cause many holde opinion that
the bodies dye, never to be made par
takers of joy or payne in the worlde to
come. But we in this article professe
the contrary, acknowledging, ye those
our bodies, & so that flesh of ours shall
rise agayne, and enter into life everla
sting.

Of this word Resurrection or ri
sing againe, I have spoken in the ex
position of that article, The third day
he rose againe from the dead. But
nowe this worde fleshe doth a great
deale more significantly expresse the
resurrection of this fleshe, than if we
should say the resurrection of the body
Verily Cyprian sayth, that in some
churches of the East, this article was
thus pronounced: I befeeve the resur
reetion of this fleshe. And Augustine
also in the tenth chapter of his booke
De fide & Symbolo, sayth: Wee must
without doubting beleeve, that this
visible, which is properly called flesh,
shall rise againe. The Apostle Paul
doth seeme, as it were, with his finger
to point at this flesh, when hee saithe
This corruptible must put on incor
ruption. when hee saieth: This, hee
doth, as it were, put out his finger un
to this flesh. This hath Augustine.
Moreover, Saynt Hierome compel
leth John, Bishoppe of Jierusalem
openly to confesse the resurrectiou of
the flesh, not of the bodie onely. Veshe
saith he, hath one definition, and the
bodie an other. All flesh is a body:but
everie bodie is not feshe. That is
fleshe properly, which is compact of
bloud, veynes, bones, and synewes.
A bodie, although it be called fleshe,
yet sometimes is said to be of like sub
stance to the firmament, or to the aire,
which is not subiect to touthing or
seeing: and oftentimes too, may be
both touthed and seene. A wall is a
bodie, but it is not flesh. Thus much
out of Hierome. Let us therefore be
leeve, that mens bodies which are ta
ken of the earth, and which living me
heare about, wherein they live, and
are, which also die, and turne into dust
and ashes, That those bodies (I saie)
are quickened and live againe.

But thou demaundest howe this
flesh being once resolved into dust and
ashes, and so into nothing, can rise a
gaine in the former shape and sub
stance: as when it is torne with the
teeth of beastes, or consumed to no
thing with the flame of fire, and when
in the grave there is to be founde but
a small and little quantitie of dustie
polder. I referre thee to the omnipo
tencie of God, which the Apostle spake
of where he sayth: Christ hath trans
fourmed this vile bodie of ours, to
make it conformable to his glorious
bodie, by the polver wherein hee can
make all thinges subiect to himelfe,
Wherefore he that in the beginning,
when as yet there was not a man in
the worlde, could bring foorth man out
of the dust of the earth, although the
same man be again resolved into that,
out of which hee was taken, I meane
into earth, as the saying is, Dust thou
art, and into dust shalt thou returne
againe: Pet notwithstanding, the
same God againe at the ende of the
worlde, is able to raise man out of the
earth. For the Lorde in the Gospell
sayth plainely: The houre shall come
wherein all they that are in the graves,
shall heare the voyce of the sonne
of God, and shall come forth, they that
have done good to the resurreetion of
life, and they that have done evill to
the resurrection of judgement. And
nowe by faith wee are throughly per
swaded, as the Apostle saith, that hee
that hath promised is able also to per
forme. Ther are moreover livelie
examples of this matter, and most e
vident testimonies of the holy Scrip
ture. Jonas is swallowed up of the
Whale in the Syrian sea, but the 3.
day after hee is cast up againe alive
uppon the shoare out of the beastes
entrailes, which is a token, that the
flesh shall verily rise againe.
Wherefore that is not hard to be be
leeved, that in the Apocalips is saide, ye
The Sea casteth uppe her dead. The
force of fire had no force to hurt the
three companions of Daniel, yea the
rage of wilde beastes (contrarie to
nature) abstained from biting Dantel
himselfe: What marvell is it there
fore, if at this day, neither the force of
fire, nor rage of wilde beastes, is able
to resist the polver of God being dispo
sed to raise his creatures up againes
Did not our Lord Christ raise up La
Farus when he had lien three daies in
the grave, yea and stancke too, to life a
gaine: Did not he himelf, having once
broken the tyrannie of death, rise by
againe the thirde day from the deads
did he not rise againe in the same sub
stance of fleshe, and forme of bodie,
wherein he hanged on the Crosse, and
being taken downe from the Crosse,
was buried: Not without good cause
do we looke backe to Christ, which is
called the first begotten among ye dead,
so often as we thinke in what manner
the resurrection of our flesh shall be.
For the memders shall rise againe in
A
the sameorder, that the heade is risen
up before them in: Tee verily shall
not rise againe the thirde day after
our death, but in our maner and order
shall wee rise at the last day, yea and
that too in the verie same body where
in now we live.
I will adde a fewe testimonies to
proove the resurrection of our flesh.
Job confessing his faith touthing the
resurrection of the dead in his great
weakenesse, affliction and fickenesse,
saith: I knowe that iny redeemer li
veth, and that in the last daie l shall
rise out of the earth, and shall be clad
againe with my skinne, and in my flesh
I shall see God: whom even I my selfe
shall sce, and my cies shall behold and
vone other. This hope is layde up in
my bosome. This testimonie is so e
vident as that it needeth no larger an
exposition.
No lesse evident are those testimo
nies out of Claie, chap26. Ezek. 37.
Psalme 15. Math. 22. John 56.11.
Throughout the Actes in everie place
is often repeated the resurrection of ye
dead. saint Paul in the 15. cha. of his
first Epistle to the Corinthians, doeth
make a full discourse of this resurrec
tion. In the fourth chapter of his 2. E
pistle he saith: we which live are al
waies delivered to death, for Jesus
sake, that the life of Jesus also might
appeare in our mortall flesh. See now
what coulde be spoken more plainely,
than that the life of Christ shall bee
made to appeare in this mortall flesh
of ours: For by and by after he sayth:
We knowe that he hath raised up the
Lorde Jesus, shall raise us up also by
the meanes of Jesus. And in the fifth
chapter againe: wee must all ap
peare before the judgement seate of
Christ (saith he) that everie man may
receive the workes of his bodie, ac
cording to that hee hath done, whe
ther it bee good or evill. Therefore
these verie bodies of ours shall rise a
gaine in the day of judgement.
And nowe (dearely beloved) I have to
declare unto you in what manner our
bodies shall rise againe, and of what
forte they shall be in the resurrection
In the shuttiug uppe and ende of all
ages or of this world, our Lord Jesus
Christ shall come to iudgement with
great maiestie, and then whomsoever
that daie shall finde alive, they shal in
a moment of time be chaunged, and
first I saye ) shall all they that died
from the first Adam to the last that
shall die, rise uppe againe, and in their
owne flesh stande among the living
that are chaunged before the Tribu
nall seate of Christ, looking for that
last pronounced sentence in judge
ment.
This doth Paul set downe in these
wordes, Loe, I tell you a mysterie, we
shall not all verily sleepe, but we shall
all be chaunged in a moment of time
in the twinckling of an eye, at the
founde of the last trumpe: For it shall
founde, and the dead shall rise againe
incorruptibly, and we shall be chaun
ged. For this corruptible must put on
incorruption, and this mortall must
put on immortalitle.
By this evident testimonie of the
Apostle, we may gather in what fa
shion our bodies shall be in that resur
rection: Verily our bodies shall bee
none other in the resurrection than
now they be, this onely excepted, that
they shal be cleane without all corrup
tion, and corruptible affection. For
the Apostle saith, The dead shall rise
againe: And we shalbe chaunged.
And againe pointing expresly and
precisely to these verie bodies which
here wee beare about, he saith: This
corruptible, This mortall, yea, This
bodie I saie, and no other, as Job al
so witnessed, shall rise againe: and that
shall rise againe incorruptible, which
was corruptible : that shal kise againe
immortall, which before the resur
rection was mortall. So then this
body of ours in the resurrection shalbe
set free from all evill affections and
passions, from all corruption: but the
substance therof shall not bee brought
to naught, it shall not bee changed in
to a spirite, it shall not loose the own
and proper shape. And this body ve
rily because of that purification and
cleansing from those dregs, yea and ra
ther because of these heavenly and di
vine gifts, is called both a spirituall
body, and also a glorious and purified
body,
For Paul in the third to the Phi
lippians sayth: Our conversation is
in heaven, from whence we looke for
the saviour the Lord lesus Christ, who
shall chaunge our vile bodie that it
maie bee made like unto his glorious
body,
See heere, the Apostle calleth not
our resurrection from the dead, a
transubstantiation, or losse of the sub
staunce of our body, but a changing:
then also shewing what kinde of bo
dy that chaunged body is, hee calleth it
a glorious body, not without all shape,
and voyd of fashion, but augmented
in glory : yea he setteth before us the
very body of our Lord Jesus Christ,
wherein hee sheweth us what fashion
our bodies shall have beeyng in glory,
For in plaine words he faith: He shal
make our vile bodie like to his glori
ous body,
Let us therefore see what kind of
body our Lord had after his resurre
ction : it was neyther turned into
a ghost, nor brought to nothing, nor
yet not able to be known by the shape
and figure: For shewing them his
handes and feete, that were easily
knowne by the poynt of the nayles
wherewith hee was crucified, he said:
Sce, for I ameven hee, to wit, cladde
againe with the same body wherein I
hung uppon the Crosse,
For speaking yet more plainely, d
prooving, that that bodie of his, was
not a spirituall substaunce, hee saide:
A spirite hath not fleshe and bones as
yee see that I have. Hee hath there
fore a purified body, flesh and bones
and the very same memders which
hee had when as yet his body was not
purified. And for this cause, did the
same Lorde offer to Thomas his side,
and the scarres of his five woundes,
to bee felt and handled, to the end,
that wee shoulde not doubt, but that
his very body was raysed up agayne,
Hee did both eate aud drinke with his
Disciples , as Peter in the Acts wit
nesseth before Cornelius, that al men
might knowe, that the very selfe
same body, that died, rose from death
agayne.
Now although this body bee com
prehended within a certaine lyiited
place, not dispersed all over and everie
where, although it have a just quan
tity, sigure, or shape, and a just weight
with the owne kinde and nature, yet
not withstanding it is free from every
passion, corruption and infirmitye.
For the body of the Lorde once ray
sed uppe, was in the Gardeyne, and
not in the Sepulchre, when the wo
men came to annoynt it, it meeteth
them by the waye as they returue
from the Sepulchre, and offereth it
selfe to beeseene of Magdalene in the
Gardeine : it goeth in companie to E
maus, with the two Disciples that
iourneyed to Emaus: in the meane
time while hee was with them in bo
dy, hee was not among the other Dis
ciples: when they twayne are retur
ned to the eleven, the Lord himelfe at
evening is present with them: He
goeth before his Disciples into Gali
le : presently after hee commeth into
Jurie againe, where his body was ta
ken up from mount Olivet into heave.
All this doth proove the certaine veri
tie of Christ his bodie. But because
this bodie (although it be a true and
very body of the owne proper kind,
place, disposition, and of the owne pro
per shape, and nature) is called a glo
rified and glorious bodie, I will saie
somewhat of that glory, which verily
is incident to the true shape and sub
stance of the body once raised uppe a
gaine.
First glory in this sense is used for
a lightsomnesse and shining bright
nesse. For Paul saith, that the children
of Israel for the glory of Moses coun
tenance, coulde not beholde with their
eies the face of Moses : so then a glo
rious body is a bright and shining bo
dy. A very good proofe of this did our
Lord shew, even a little before his re
surrection, whe it pleased him to give
to his Disciples a small taste of the
glory to come, and for that cause took a
side certaine whom he had chosen into
the top of a certaine hil, where he was
transsigured before them, so that the
fashion of his countenance did shine as
the sunne, and his clothes were white
& glistered as the light. The Lord veri
ly had stil the same bodily substance, &
the same members of the body, but
they we re transeigured.
But it is manifest, that that transfi
guratio was in ye accidents: For light
and brightnesse was added, so that the
shape & substance of the countenaunce
and bodie remayning as it was, the
countenaunce and body did glister as
the Sunne & the light. And although
wee reade not, that the bodye of the
Lord did within those 40. daies, wher
in h
his Disciples, make manifest & spread
abroade the brightnesse which it had,
and that by reason of the dispensation,
whereby also he did eate with his dis
ciples, notwithstanding that clarified
bodies neede not foode or nourishment
at all : yet neverthelesse his bodie shi
neth nowe in Heaven, as John in the
first of the Apocalipse witnesseth, and
the sacred Scriptures laye an allured
hope before us, that even our bodies
also shall in the resurrection bee like
wise clarified. For the Lorde himelfe
in the Gospell alleadging the wordes
of Daniel, saith: Then shall the righ
teous shine as the Sonne in his fathers
kingdome. For this cause the glori
ous bodies are called also clarified of
the clearnesse of that heavenly bright
nesse, wherewith they glister and are
adorned.
Secondarily, glorie and vilenesse
are made contraries. For Paul saith,
Hee shall chaunge our vile bodie, to
make it in fashion like ro his glorious
bodie. In these wordes, Vilenesse and
Glorie, are set the one agaynst the o
ther. Vilenesse comprehendeth the
whole packe of miseries and infirmi
ties, passions and affections, which
for sinne was layde uppon the bodie,
From all which our bodies are pur
ged in the resurrection of life: so that
then the glorious bodies are bodies
dreined from the dregges of all cor
ruption, passions and infirmities, and
clad with eternitie, heavenlie feeling
and glorie. For the Apostle saith: It is
sowen in corruption, itriseth in in
corruption: it is sowen in dishonour,
it riseth in glorie: it is sowen in infir
mitie, it riseth in poler : it is sowen a
naturall bodie, it tiseth a spiritual bo
die. The giftes therefore of the glo
rious & clarified bodies are very great
and manye, as incorruption, glorie,
polver and the quickening spirite. For
the Apostle himselfe shewing what he
meant by ye naturall & spirituall body,
addeth this immediatly & saith: There
is a naturalll bodye, and there is a spiri
tuall bodie : as it is written. The first
man Adam was made a living soule,
and the last Adam was made a dure
kening spirite. And yet agayne more
plainely he sayth: Howbeit that is not
first which is spirituall, but that which
is naturall, and then that which is spy
rituall. The first man is of the earth
earthly:the second man is the Lord from
heaven. As is the earthly, suth are they
that are earthly: fas is the heavenly,
suth are they also that are heavenlie,
And as we have born the image of the
earthly, so shal wee beare the image of
the heavenlie. So then Paul calleth
that naturall bodie and earthly body,
which wee have of our first father A
dam, whose quickening is of the soule
and by it doeth live. And hee calleth
the spiritual body, and heavenly body,
which wee have of Christ, and made
to the likenesse of the body of Christ,
which although it bee a very body in
deede, and the fleshe thereof bee very
flesh indeed, yet notwithstanding it is
quickened & preserved by the spirit of
Christ, and needeth not any polver be
getative.
Although therefore these very bo
dies & memders which now we heare
shall after the resurrection be in Hea
ven, yet neverthelesse because they
are clarified and cleansed from all cor
ruption, and feeling of the natural bo
die, there shall not be verily any na
tural or corruptible sense or affection,
nor use of the carnall body and mem
bers. And this doth the Lorde affirme
agaynst the Sadduces that breamed
of marriages in Heaven, or rather by
that absurditie, made a mocke of the
resurrection, where hee sayeth: The
sonnes, of this worlde marrie wives,
and give in marriage: but they that
shal be thought worthie of that world
and of the resurreetion from the dead
doe neither marrie wives, nor give in
marriage: neither can they die anie
more. For they are equall to the An
gels, and are the sonnes of God, assoone
as they be the sonnes of resurrection.
To which effect also Paul saythr Vlesh.
and bloud can not inherite the king
dome of GOD. And least peradven
ture any man shoulde mistake hys
words, and thinke that he spake of the
substance of the flesh, he addeth imme
diatly this for interpretation therof, &
saith, Neither shall corruption inherit
incorruption.
Wherefore flesh & bloud, that is to
saye, the affections and lustes of the
fleshe, shall not bee in the Clect that
live in heaven. For the ioyes of Hea
ven doe differ a great deale from the
ioyes of the earth, & are so farre foorth
of another condition, that they cannot
admit such corrupt creatures to be in
heritours of them, & for that cause the
corruptible bodies must first be purged
from all corruption, & by that meanes,
purely clarified. The Turkes therfore
are deceyved that looke for earthly
ioyes,
Moreover the bodies of the wicked
shall also rise againe. For Paul in the
Actes saith: I beleeve all that is writ
ten in the Lawe and the Prophetes
hoping in God that the resurrection
of the dead, which they themselves
looke for also, shalbe both of the just,
and uniust. See heere, the Apostle saith
of the uniust also. But in this resur
rection there shall not be taken out of
their bodies, the infirmitie, corrupti
on, dishonour and miserie : for even
then that very body rising againe and
dishonour, shall by the judgement and
polver of God be surely shut in disho
nour, and corruption, and so be con
demned for ever to beare endlesse tor
mentes, and in death and corruption
shall neither die nor yet corrupt : that
even as on earth are found certayne
bodies that doe indure even in the
fire, so the cursed bodies of the wicked
shal not be worne out nor broken with
any torments whatsoever, for every
minute they shal receive new strength
to suffer , and so by continuall susfe
ring shall abide their deserved punish
ments for ever and ever and without
all end. For the Lorde in the Gospell
sayeth, They that have done evill
shall rise agayne to the resurreetion of
damnation, that is, to an induring &
everlasting damnation. And Daniel
before him sayde, And the multitude
of them that sleepe in the dust of the
earth shall awake, some to everlasting
life, and some to shame and perpetual
contempt.
And in the Gospell agayne, the Lord
sayeth: Their worme dieth not, and
their fire is not duenched. And the
very same wordes used Elay before
him in his 66. Chapter. Tee must
alwayes therefore have that saying
of the Lorde in our hearts, Jeare him
that can destroy both the body ethe
soule in hell. Thus much hitherto tou
ching the resurrection of the flesh.
The last Article of our belief, which
with good lucke shutteth up the rest, is
this, And life everlasting. Wee have
heard and understood that the foules
of men are immortall, and that our
bodies doe rise againe in the ende of
the worlde. Vee have confessed that
this is our beleefe. It followeth now
in the latter end of the Creede, whi
ther it is, that the immortal soule, and
body raised up again shal come. Ther
fore in our confession we say: And life)
everlasting, that is, I believe that :
shall have life, and live for ever both
in body & soule. And that everlasting
nesse verily is perpetual & hath no end,
as a little before is proved out of the
holy Scriptures.
Moreover, the foules are made par
takers of this eternall life immediat
ly after they are departed out of the
bodies, as the Lord himselfe witnes
seth saying, Te that beleeveth in the
Sonne of GOD shall not come into
judgement, but hath escaped from
death to life. As for the bodies they
are buried and doe putrifie, and yet so
notwitstanding, that they shal not bee
without life for ever. But they shal
then at length be received into eter
nall life, when beeing raysed up, they
shall after: the time of judgement bee
caught into the ayre, there to meete
Christ that they may forever bee with
the Lorde. For then doe the foules re
turne Sit of heaven every one to his
owne hgdie, that the whole, perfect, &
fil man may live for ever both in soule
and body. For the soule of Christ dy
ing on the Crosse did out of hand de
part into Paradise, and the thirde
day after returned to the body, which
rose againe and ascended into heaven.
Even as therfore, eternal life came to
the head Christ, so shall it also come to
al and every membder of Christ,
Now, whereas Paul citing Clay,
sayth: what the eye hath not seene,
nor the eare hearde, nor hath at any
time come into the heart of man, that
hath the Lord prepared for them that
love him. I suppose verily if all were
sayd touching eternall life, that might
be spoken by al the men of al ages that
be throughly touched.
ever were or shall be, yet that scarcely
the very least part therof hath or shall
For how so ever the Scripture doeth
witheloquent and sigurative speches,
with allusions and harde Sentences
most, plainely shew the shadow of that
life, and those ioyes, yet notwithstan
ding, all that is little or nothing in co
parison to speake of, untill that day do
come wherein we shall with unspeak
able ioye, beholde God himelfe, the
creator of al things in his glory, Christ
our saviour in his Maiestie, and final
ly all the blessed foules, Angels, Pa
triarches, Prophetes, Apostles, Mar
tyrs, our Fathers, all nations, all the
hoast of Heaven, and lastly the whole
divine and heavenlie glorie. Most
truely therefore sayde Aurelius Au
gustine, Lib, de Eivit. Dei. 22. Cap. 29.
when it is demaunded of mee what
the Saintes shall doe in that spirituall
bodie3. J aunswere not that which I
nowesee, but that that l beleeve. I say
therefore that they shall see God in
that spirituall bodie. And againe, If
I should saie the trueth, I knowe not
in what sorte that action, duietnesse
and rest shall be. For the peace of
God doth passe all understanding.
To be short, we shall see God face to
face, we shall be silled with the com
panie of God, and yet be never wearie
of him. And the face of God is not that
countonaunce that appeareth in us,
but is a most delectable revealing and
inioying of God, which no mortall
tongue can worthily declare. Goe to
then (dearely beloved brethren) let us
believe and live, that when wee shall
depart from hence wee may in verie
deede have triall of those uuspeakable
ioyes of the eternal life to come, which I
nowe we doe believe.
Hitherto have I throughout the
foure last Articles declared unto you
the fruite and ende of Christian faith,
Faith leaneth upon one God the Fa
ther, the Sonne, and the holy Ghost,
which sanctifieth ye faithfull, & purgeth
and halloweth a Church to him elfe,
which Church hath a communion
with God and all saintes. All the
offences of which Church God pardo
neth and forgiveth. And doeth pre
serue it both soule and bodie. For as
the saints soules can not die, so God
rayseth up their bodies againe , and
maketh them glorious and everla
staing, to the end that the whole man
may for ever live in heaven, with.
the Lord: to whom be praise
and glory world with
out end. Amen.
